update.description:
The easiest way to test is to change the hokuyo laser model to use `gpu_ray` as its type and comment out the use of `libRayPlugin` in model.sdf

Key changes:

- Fix some cases where the range values are not correct

- Fix instantiating multiple gpu ray sensors

- Add gpu laser unit and integration tests

- Add noise model

- Enable laser scan data publishing

- Add visualization in gzclient

- A bunch of style fixes

Known issue:

- It was found that skyx causes laser range values to be clipped. I did a workaround that just sets it to invisible when doing the first laser rendering pass (line 384 in gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.cc). There maybe another easier/cleaner way to do this but this is sufficient for now to make things work.

Update: 

- Fix sampling of range ranges when gpu ray sensor is pitched or rolled. 

- Added test world file: gpu_laser2.world
update.title: gpu ray sensor

content.raw: Trying to reproduce the test I was unable to locate the gpu_laser2.world in the repo? Did I miss something?
content.html: Trying to reproduce the test I was unable to locate the gpu_laser2.world in the repo? Did I miss something?

content.raw: I guess this might be an intended/known/inevitable issue due to z-buffer limitations, but the lidar goes through obstacles that are below min range (e.g. the camera part of the multisense below the lidar).
content.html: I guess this might be an intended/known/inevitable issue due to z-buffer limitations, but the lidar goes through obstacles that are below min range (e.g. the camera part of the multisense below the lidar).

content.raw:
Using a different machine and atlas model I still see the same problems. I'm not sure whether this already occurred during my video recorded yesterday but the gpu lidar also seems to completely ignore heightmaps on my work pc: http://i.imgur.com/GQ0Pnkk.jpg   ... looking at the video recorded on my laptop it doesn't seem like this problem occurred there. My laptop used some mobile nvidia gpu while my this pc uses a gtx 680.

edit: the problem was Ogre 1.8.1 ... it works when using the default 1.7.4 ubuntu package installation.
content.html:
Using a different machine and atlas model I still see the same problems. I'm not sure whether this already occurred during my video recorded yesterday but the gpu lidar also seems to completely ignore heightmaps on my work pc: http://i.imgur.com/GQ0Pnkk.jpg ... looking at the video recorded on my laptop it doesn't seem like this problem occurred there. My laptop used some mobile nvidia gpu while my this pc uses a gtx 680.

edit: the problem was Ogre 1.8.1 ... it works when using the default 1.7.4 ubuntu package installation.

content.raw: I just removed Ogre 1.8.1 (I don't know why i had this ... I think gazebo used to require 1.8.1 half a year ago to render shadows properly or something like that) and it works with Ogre 1.7.4.
content.html: I just removed Ogre 1.8.1 (I don't know why i had this ... I think gazebo used to require 1.8.1 half a year ago to render shadows properly or something like that) and it works with Ogre 1.7.4.

content.raw: Nah, running this branch and atlas_meshes merged with drcsim_2.5 right now.
content.html: Nah, running this branch and atlas_meshes merged with drcsim_2.5 right now.

content.raw: I am using ogre 1.7.4. I get valid range values with heightmap, see pic: https://www.dropbox.com/s/odj1o2x8m7l3hs5/gpulaser_heightmap.png. Are you testing it on your fork with missing textures? Not sure if that's the problem or not.
content.html: I am using ogre 1.7.4. I get valid range values with heightmap, see pic: https://www.dropbox.com/s/odj1o2x8m7l3hs5/gpulaser_heightmap.png. Are you testing it on your fork with missing textures? Not sure if that's the problem or not.

content.raw:
It does look like it works properly with a spinning lidar now. 

Still ignores heightmaps on my pc though (i guess the sensor acquires the z-buffer before heightmaps are drawn in?). I'm compiling against Ogre 1.8.1 if that matters.
content.html:
It does look like it works properly with a spinning lidar now.

Still ignores heightmaps on my pc though (i guess the sensor acquires the z-buffer before heightmaps are drawn in?). I'm compiling against Ogre 1.8.1 if that matters.

content.raw: Just pushed a fix for it and tested it on atlas in a world with heightmap, values look correct now. Let me know if it works for you.
content.html: Just pushed a fix for it and tested it on atlas in a world with heightmap, values look correct now. Let me know if it works for you.

update.description:
The easiest way to test is to change the hokuyo laser model to use `gpu_ray` as its type and comment out the use of `libRayPlugin` in model.sdf

Key changes:

- Fix some cases where the range values are not correct

- Fix instantiating multiple gpu ray sensors

- Add gpu laser unit and integration tests

- Add noise model

- Enable laser scan data publishing

- Add visualization in gzclient

- A bunch of style fixes

Known issue:

- It was found that skyx causes laser range values to be clipped. I did a workaround that just sets it to invisible when doing the first laser rendering pass (line 384 in gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.cc). There maybe another easier/cleaner way to do this but this is sufficient for now to make things work.

Update: 

- Fix sampling of range ranges when gpu ray sensor is pitched or rolled.
update.title: gpu ray sensor

content.raw: thanks for spotting this problem. I'll look into it
content.html: thanks for spotting this problem. I'll look into it

content.raw:
So the good news is: it does run faster on the current heightmaps than the ODE based lidar (this does not mean that gazebo heightmaps are awesome now! there's still 3 or 4 bugs left :| ).

The bad news however is: it seems to be "kinda" buggy when rotating the sensor and/or when using it with Atlas: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hqop4k_G4xc

Sorry for the laggy video, it was recorded on my laptop which also explains the low real-time factor - the missing textures are due to me mixing this branch with the drcsim textures fork.

As you can see in the video the lidar seems to "crop off" regions / detects obstacles that aren't actually there / whatever is going on as it rotates ... so this seems to be either an issue of the lidar rotating or an issue with Atlas' head model or a combination of both.

The sensor used for Atlas was

    <sensor name="head_hokuyo_sensor" type="gpu_ray">
      <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
      <visualize>true</visualize>
      <update_rate>40</update_rate>
      <topic>gpu_scan</topic>
      <ray>
        <scan>
          <horizontal>
            <samples>720</samples>
            <resolution>1</resolution>
            <min_angle>-1.570796</min_angle>
            <max_angle>1.570796</max_angle>
          </horizontal>
        </scan>
        <range>
          <min>0.10</min>
          <max>30.0</max>
          <resolution>0.01</resolution>
        </range><!--
        <noise>
          <type>gaussian</type>
          <!- Noise parameters based on published spec for Hokuyo laser
               achieving "+-30mm" accuracy at range < 10m.  A mean of 0.0m and
               stddev of 0.01m will put 99.7% of samples within 0.03m of the true
               reading.-> 
          <mean>0.0</mean>
          <stddev>0.01</stddev>
        </noise>-->
      </ray><!--
      <plugin filename="libgazebo_ros_laser.so" name="gazebo_ros_head_hokuyo_controller">
        <topicName>/multisense_sl/laser/scan</topicName>
        <frameName>head_hokuyo_frame</frameName>
      </plugin>-->
    </sensor>
content.html:
So the good news is: it does run faster on the current heightmaps than the ODE based lidar (this does not mean that gazebo heightmaps are awesome now! there's still 3 or 4 bugs left :| ).

The bad news however is: it seems to be "kinda" buggy when rotating the sensor and/or when using it with Atlas: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hqop4k_G4xc

Sorry for the laggy video, it was recorded on my laptop which also explains the low real-time factor - the missing textures are due to me mixing this branch with the drcsim textures fork.

As you can see in the video the lidar seems to "crop off" regions / detects obstacles that aren't actually there / whatever is going on as it rotates ... so this seems to be either an issue of the lidar rotating or an issue with Atlas' head model or a combination of both.

The sensor used for Atlas was

<sensor name="head_hokuyo_sensor" type="gpu_ray">
  <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>
  <visualize>true</visualize>
  <update_rate>40</update_rate>
  <topic>gpu_scan</topic>
  <ray>
    <scan>
      <horizontal>
        <samples>720</samples>
        <resolution>1</resolution>
        <min_angle>-1.570796</min_angle>
        <max_angle>1.570796</max_angle>
      </horizontal>
    </scan>
    <range>
      <min>0.10</min>
      <max>30.0</max>
      <resolution>0.01</resolution>
    </range><!--
    <noise>
      <type>gaussian</type>
      <!- Noise parameters based on published spec for Hokuyo laser
           achieving "+-30mm" accuracy at range < 10m.  A mean of 0.0m and
           stddev of 0.01m will put 99.7% of samples within 0.03m of the true
           reading.-> 
      <mean>0.0</mean>
      <stddev>0.01</stddev>
    </noise>-->
  </ray><!--
  <plugin filename="libgazebo_ros_laser.so" name="gazebo_ros_head_hokuyo_controller">
    <topicName>/multisense_sl/laser/scan</topicName>
    <frameName>head_hokuyo_frame</frameName>
  </plugin>-->
</sensor>

update.description:
The easiest way to test is to change the hokuyo laser model to use `gpu_ray` as its type and comment out the use of `libRayPlugin` in model.sdf

Key changes:

- Fix some cases where the range values are not correct

- Fix instantiating multiple gpu ray sensors

- Add gpu laser unit and integration tests

- Add noise model

- Enable laser scan data publishing

- Add visualization in gzclient

- A bunch of style fixes

Known issue:

- It was found that skyx causes laser range values to be clipped. I did a workaround that just sets it to invisible when doing the first laser rendering pass (line 384 in gazebo/rendering/GpuLaser.cc). There maybe another easier/cleaner way to do this but this is sufficient for now to make things work.
update.title: gpu ray sensor

content.raw: Yes unless someone changes the ogre material script. I've put in GZ_ASSERTS just to make sure it's not null
content.html: Yes unless someone changes the ogre material script. I've put in GZ_ASSERTS just to make sure it's not null
